comments.commentBody: Spanish soccer fans chant OLE. so the end of a threat would be OR I ...OLE!
The original on which that was based was Samuel Johnson, in 1775

Cashman NEVER made good deals, my friend. He did nothing more than Shylock small market teams who were facing impending free agency into giving up a David Cone for scraps. Or simply outbidding the world for a Jason Giambi or Mike Mussina.

Once the playing field for GM's was somewhat leveled? Well, we've all seen Brian Cashman's true baseball acumen on full display over the last decade - billions spent, wasted draft picks, moronic trades, even dumber non-trades and just one purchased World Series to show for it. And who can forget the shameless retiring of Yankee numbers - posada? Really????

Cashman is a disgrace who should've been fired a decade ago.

Please... the current state of the Yankees is at the feet of Cashman and the kinder gentler Hal Steinbrenner. Low draft picks is not an excuse for zero home grown talent. They talked needing a good farm system for years. Over priced broken down free agents and poor trades is on the GM. Cashman has been on the job way to long and sadly current ownership does not have the nerve to find new leadership. The rebuild will take considerable time with no promises as more often than not young talent doesn't reach full potential. Maybe the empty seats and sinking revenue will create real change... new front office management.

JEM......You are 100% right! Most people don't realize that the '90s Yankees Dynasty was created by others and Cashman is somehow credited with that successes. Even the 2009 Championship, can be attributed to the 90's core group of players.

Low draft picks? Mike Piazza was taken in the 62nd round, a round that no longer even exists, and he turned out to be a decent pkayer. And he's not the only one.
On the other hand, the Mets drafted Steve Chilcott ahead of Reggie Jackson...

If Harper becomes a free agent after the 2018 season he'll be 26 years old. Alex Rodriguez was 32 when he signed his current ten year deal. No contract is risk-free but that's a huge difference.

That being said, for reasons described in this article, I fully expect the Nats to give him a huge extension.

Elsewhere in this paper is an OpEd by former ambassador McFaul; it's not a pretty story, but worth a look.
"Ambassador Michael McFaul was there when the promise of democracy came to Russia—and when it began to fade"
http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/08/11/watching-eclipse

This appears to be the model Trump admires. Unfortunately, Trump also appears to be abysmally ignorant about world history and the way things work outside his gilded empire. You see, he doesn't care; his attention is all on his personal gain and what he can get out of people. The Russians were happy to play, because they could see through him.
Neither Warren nor Markey, terrific Democrats (he's the best on climate) are in any danger of losing their Senate seats. We need more Democrats in both Senate and House.

Martin, if you watched ESPN tonight, you saw a wild game and, as a Cubs fan for at least 66 years, the wildest Cubs finish I can recall ever. Down 6-0 the Cubs fought back to tie in the 9th and in the 11th inning win on a squeeze bunt by a starting pitcher who is pinch hitting. More vodka, please. It's time to celebrate.
We won two straight.  Nothing that dramatic, but at least no triple plays.

Clearly a well written indictment of the Republican Party and, in particular, of their nominee for the Presidency of the United States.  In fact, if every single, or even more than 50% of the Republican Party read this carefully, they would revolt and ask Trump to step down.  Unfortunately, this editorial is written for the readers of the New York Times.  How many members of the "stupid party" read the New York Times?  What percentage of the "stupid party" are just like Trump in terms of their interest and ability in reading.  Significant.  So, I ask the author and the New York Times, just how to do you plan to distribute this truly accurate and important essay amongst the "stupid party" and more of the members of the "smart party."  This is excellent writing and sentiment, but are you just going to write it for all the intellectually superior readers of your excellent newspaper?  Are you just going to be satisfied with preaching to the choir or are you doing to do something about it?  Inquiring minds would like to know.

The party of stupid is followed by stupid people. You could create a television ad in which the entire cast of "Duck Dynasty" read this editorial  while wielding guns and drinking beer at a Nascar rally and the people who support Trump would still call them traitors, or communists, or shills for the liberal elite. You over estimate them. No common sense can touch them. It's like trying to get your 85 year old grandfather to stop being a racist. It just won't happen.
Max Boot is a Republican.  Maybe he can publish this article in a Republican leaning newspaper.  But would they accept it?

Ralph -- Key insight here you make. While it's intellectually satisfying to highlight the intellectual void of the current Republican party created by their nurture of ignorance and identity politics in their party's membership, the piece does nothing to advance the prospects of Clinton for President.

So I'm left wondering if the NY Times, the paper of intellectuals who, having done so much advocacy journalism to advance the candidate of "Clinton Democrat Dynasty Inc, LLC", who is demonstrably more unelectable than Sanders would have been, has any pragmatic ideas about how to get those disenfranchised, angry, sinking white middle class voters to vote for the Lady in the White Pantsuit? Calling them names isn't likely to work.

Hey Mr. Rosenthal, as indeed we now see with the revelations of DNC emails that internal to the DNC was the free ideation on how (a supposedly neutral arbiter) could work to defeat Sanders, it's now brass tacks time. What's your plan to get Clinton elected? Come on into the gooey tar pit where we now have to figure out how to get the corporate candidate with the support of the population of middle America white-hot with rage against corporate America. You helped put is in this tar pit, so what's the plan now? For starters, let's take rigging the national election off the table.

Yeah, nothing like a good mountain man.

I guess a toy doll is in contrast with a living doll, but I'm not dumb enough to go there.

The answer to wrong track is probably more related to the lowest approval rating of Congress....almost ever. It's done nothing in the years of Republican control and exercised every opportunity to oppose everything Obama ever since.

It has done nothing for the American people, either in their jobs and wages, opportunity for education and employment, job creating infrastructure projects or tax relief.

The fact of the matter is that the Republican Congress has dedicated itself only to the defeat of anything and everything associated with Obama, just as McConnell promised eight years ago.

Obama's greatest failure is in refusing the bully pulpit to call them out, in the wistful thinking of an intellectual dealing with those who would deny science itself for political motives.

When a President gets a favorable rating and Congress the lowest historically possible, how hard can it be to discern why folks just don't see us headed in the right direction?
Martin, I was thinking more like cougar.

How do you know they are not? When was the last time they told you who they were investigating and why?

You think these investigations just take a couple of days, you never got a clearance did you?
We won two straight.  Nothing that dramatic, but at least no triple plays.

Dear Mr. Boot, regarding your comment: "There are still some thoughtful Republican leaders exemplified by House Speaker Paul D. Ryan, who devised an impressive new budget plan for his party." You may want to revise that after reading the comments of economist NYTimes' Paul Krugman who said:

"Look, Ryan hasn’t ‘crunched the numbers’; he has just scribbled some stuff down, without checking at all to see if it makes sense. He asserts that he can cut taxes without net loss of revenue by closing unspecified loopholes; he asserts that he can cut discretionary spending to levels not seen since Calvin Coolidge, without saying how; he asserts that he can convert Medicare to a voucher system, with much lower spending than now projected, without even a hint of how this is supposed to work." Plenty more available. Ryan is a phoney.

Without the ACA my husband who is fighting cancer would have long since lost his supplemental insurance and Medicare only covers 80%.  With Ryan's voucher system he wouldn't have any insurance at all.  The "death panels" would return.
Well said.  I don't see how you can couple Ryan's name with those of Lincoln or Theodore Roosevelt.  Just because you call someone a "policy wonk" or a "thinker" doesn't make him one.
And that great "thinker" George F. Will still "believes" climate change may not be a reality, or if a reality is not much of a problem.

Has anyone else seen the Travel Channel's story about the Crossword Puzzles in 1944 that almost gave away D-DAY? The puzzle is in Harvard's library. Fascinating story. Can't find a YouTube so I will elaborate tomorrow (Monday) sometime.

I haven't seen the Travel Channel story, John, but I remember hearing about those crossword puzzles years ago. I think they may have been mentioned in Cornelius Ryan's 'The Longest Day.'

It wasn't until some years later that I learned that the appearance of certain words was not entirely coincidental, even though it didn't involve espionage in any way. Interesting tale.

Yes, Rich. An agent with British Intelligence was charged with making sure nothing leaked out about Operation Overlord, the code name for the D-Day invasion. He noticed a crossword with the word UTAH (code word for one of the beaches at Normandy) and later noticed another crossword with OMAHA, another code named Normandy beach where the invasion was to occur. Finally, he noticed the word OVERLORD and concluded these were no coincidences but maybe a way of signaling the Germans of the planned invasion. British Intelligence interviewed the professor responsible for the crossword puzzles. He taught at a school where much of the staging for the invasion was located. The professor denied any knowledge or being a German spy. It turned out that he had given grids to his students and asked them to create crossword puzzles. Later it was learned that the young student who created the crossword puzzles had heard these three words and decided to include them, not knowing their significance. So, when the invasion occurred, the Allies weren’t sure if the secrecy of the operation had been compromised. It wasn’t and the Germans were caught by surprise.

Claptrap by the bucket writ here,
The issue's not "stupid'' I fear,
Greed of one percent
On their wealth intent,
And very ruthlessly it's clear.

With bigotry well larded too
By Reagan's vile Welfare Queen stew,
To turn the White Worker
To bigot berserker,
And create the Tea Party Crew.
Bravo! Thank you, Mr. Eisenberg.
Bravo! You outdid yourself today.

Thomas,
The neo-con war hawk Max Boot is supporting Hillary Clinton. He is showing his true colors.

http://www.salon.com/2016/06/10/another_neocon_endorses_clinton_calling_...

Yes we certainly need someone like you, to tell the media what to do.

You think these investigative reporters just go down to the local bar, and talk to the yahoos there, to find out who is doing what in the business world of Russia?

As a New Yorker I honestly think Trump may have been telling the truth when he said his "invitation" to Russia about e-mails was sarcasm. It sounds exactly like what a New Yorker would say.

I also think those who believe he meant he would actually date his own daughter are too literal-minded. It was just the sort of high praise Trump would give to a woman.

And so what? Neither of those is important; it's his uncaring ignorance, his outspoken nastiness and provocation of vicious hatred amongst his followers, and his "I alone" mantra, among other things, that are the real reasons to oppose him.

Mr Trump is a textbook case of "sociopath".
Anyone who believes he'd be a good public servant is like the hunter who shoots straight up and expects the bullet to bag a duck on its way down
That, and the fact that his campaign manager is/was on the payroll of some very corrupt foreign political figures.
You insult New Yorkers. It's a type of person; not about all New Yorkers or only New Yorkers.

Larry is right. Max Boot is a GOP flag-carrier, not an honest historian or analyst. The GOP went bad* when they refused to consider Teddy Roosevelt for another term in 1912. That's before Bush the Younger, Reagan, and even Eisenhower, for those who need a reminder.

* Maybe they just showed their true colors.
Max Boot writes in support of Hillary. Who's next, John Bolton? Dick Cheney?
Didn't notice any mention of Hillary, actually.
Boot never met a war he didn't like.
You often write in support of Trump. Putin next? Manafort?

Almost all the comments ignore the basic fact that, commonly, an affair is a symptom, rather than a cause, of marital problems.  A happily married person (of either gender) is much less likely than an unhappily married person to have an affair.  Dispelling the mistress will not solve any of this.  And, contrary to what most of the comments here say, the existence (dispelled or not) of a mistress does not mean the problem is "the philandering husband"--it means there are serious underlying problems in the marriage that both partners need to face, and to which both partners probably contributed, if they want the marriage to be satisfying.    It's interesting that the article totally ignores this.

I mostly agree with you, but if one member of the union is unfaithful, then it does not matter what problems existed between thr pair: the cheater is guilty. Full stop.

To me, the real tragedy is that women lack power, which leads to being trapped in the marriage. If a woman can't practically divorce, it is no wonder that men can get away with having a mistress!

You speak of addressing root causes. I could not agree more: norms and laws must be reformed so that men and women have equal power in marriage, and other institutions.

"Max Boot, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, was a foreign policy adviser to the presidential campaigns of John McCain, Mitt Romney and Marco Rubio."

If Mr. Boot was so concerned about Mr. Trump, why didn't he encourage the Republican Presidential nominees for the 2008 and 2012 election stand up and vigorously oppose Mr. Trump a year ago? Mr. Trump's personality disorder and lack of fitness to be President was obvious at that time.

The leadership of the GOP probably probably could have extinguished the Trump candidacy if they had risen with one voice and said "No, not you, not now, not ever." Their inaction brought this mess onto themselves.

Brad - Agreed. But who were the other contenders for 2016? A frightening cabal of more 'no-nothings'. Only over-weaning meanness, no concept of demographic change, no concept of either internal or external security, no concept of real world economic reality, science deniers, climate change deniers, knowledge deniers, social change deniers - 'let us pray and have a moment of silence for those who have e been killed by our bad policy and intransigence, both at home and abroad' hypocrites? Or the stupid who were put up for the highest office in the land by stupid 'leaders'?

If the leadership of the GOP had any vestige of courage or decency, and had risen up and said "No, not you, not now, not ever." , which minion would have replaced him? Carly Fiorina? Ted Cruz, who was the most frightening father anointed one of the lot? Who, who? Marco Rubio? Which one of that benighted crew would anyone in their right mind vote to lead the most powerful country in the world? The one that has more weapons on that all the other countries in the work combined?

I had never heard of Max Boot before, but his stupid endorsement of Paul Ryan has curdled his name for me.

When you defend the stupid you can count yourself among them.

@Brad

So tired of blaming Trump on the GOP, people like Max Boot, and any other person of interest.

One could also ask how the Democrats, a fine party, stood up Hillary, Bernie the Socialist, and Marty O'Malley. What the GOP did in its excess presentation of candidates the Democrats did in its dearth.

Neither has served the country well, leaving us with two primary party candidates more hated than loved, Jill Stein, and a stoner named Gary.

Our country is going through a difficult relationship with reality, presented only promises or lies (on alternating days) by the major party candidates. Truth and facts seem to be inconvenient to the debate at this time. That is how we ended up where we are.

Or they could just have rerfused to support anyone unwilling to provide his tax returns.    Ryan and McConnell could maybe save the party and their reputations if they would do this now.  They won't.  As has been said, Trump is a sympton, the problem is much deeper for the party.

You're looking in the wrong direction. Of course Trump is only a symptom, but of what? The political parties are reflections of the soul of a democracy's electorate. That is what needs to be examined. An ignorant demagogue captured one of the two parties in the U.S. What does that reflect? Where are all the conservatives who presumably make up the Republican party and who are opposed to the liberals who presumably make up the Democratic party?

What has happened? What has Republican leadership wrought since 2008 and then 2012?--especially 2012. Or, indeed, where does it begin, because I think you are spot on when you say, "...the primary vibe from the G.O.P. has become one of indiscriminate, unthinking, all-consuming anger." That's a little crude. For accuracy's sake you could say 'The soul of the G.O.P. has become one of indiscriminate, unthinking, all-consuming anger:'
"the soul" as in, the unifying force that drives the Republican Party. Can that be in the Republican electorate, but not the in leadership? Paul Ryan, for example, whom you admire, does that characterize him?

No, but something is very wrong with Mr. Ryan and all the others in a similar position in the Republican leadership, that is, if you are right about Trump and the Republican Party. Because they all support Trump for president. What's wrong with them Mr. Boot? You're the conservative intellectual, you and George Will and others. What is it?

What is going on?

It's the same thing as Democrats who will vote for Hillary "with their noses pinched". They hate her, they don't trust her, they know she is a crook -- but they tell themselves "even so, she can appoint left-leaning Justices to the Supreme Court".

Sadly, that is how our political system has DEVOLVED. The battle is actually over who gets to appoint the next Justices -- NOT who is a better or more decent or honest candidate.

"An ignorant demagogue captured one of the two parties in the U.S. What does that reflect?"

It shows where the voters are. What the GOP elite is selling, they're not buying.

Gruener Veltliner are very good wines, always suitable in LA for pre dinner drinking or with any meal short of red meat.
But vinho verdes are just as tasty, generally cheaper, and with alcohol levels as low as 8%, even more drinkable.
How can you compare drinking Gruener Veltliner vs. Vinho Verde. This would be equal to compare drinking  Dom Perignon vs. Prosecco.... ???
Well, for openers, both wines are called green; that would seem reason enough to me.
